Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: GOALI: Perfluoro(poly)ethers - a new class of drinking water contaminants

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1550222
Knappe

Because of their persistence, bioaccumulation potential, and (eco)toxicity, long-chain perfluoroalkyl substances such as perfluorooctanoic acid and perfluorooctane sulfonate are being replaced with short-chain fluorinated alternatives. Almost no information exists about the occurrence of fluorinated alternatives and their behavior during water treatment. The overall goal of the proposed research is to begin to fill this knowledge gap by studying one class of fluorinated alternatives, perfluoro(poly) ethers.

Specific research objectives include to: (1) develop a quantitative liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method for the analysis of 13 perfluoro(poly) ethers in water, (2) apply the liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method to (a) determine perfluoro(poly) ether fate in a surface water, (b) quantify perfluoro(poly) ether concentrations and mass flows at the intake of a water treatment plant, (3) in collaboration with the water utility, trace parcels of water through the plant to quantify perfluoro(poly) ether removal/transformation in full-scale water treatment processes, and (4) trace parcels of water through the water distribution system to determine perfluoro(poly) ethers fate during drinking water distribution. This data would be used to estimate human exposure to perfluoro(poly) ethers via consumption of drinking water. Given the data scarcity surrounding fluorinated alternatives, it is anticipated that the results of this research will receive wide interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The production of fluoropolymers, such as polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE, trade name Teflon), involves the use of fluoromonomers and processing aids. In the past, a common processing aid was the ammonium salt of perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA). Because PFOA is bioaccumulative, toxic, and persistent, it is no longer manufactured or used in the United States (US). In 2009, the US Environmental Protection Agency stipulated conditions for the production and commercial use of a PFOA replacement known as GenX. Apart from its production for commercial purposes, GenX and other perfluoroalkyl ether acids (PFEAs) are also generated as by-products during the production of fluoromonomers. The goals of this research were to (1) develop an analytical method for the determination of GenX and other PFEAs, (2) apply the analytical method to study the fate of emerging PFEAs in full­scale water treatment plants, laboratory­scale adsorption processes, and home filtration systems, and (3) develop data that provide the basis for outreach efforts designed to minimize concentrations of PFEAs in the drinking water of affected communities.

With respect to the first goal, a sensitive analytical method for the identification and quantification of PFEAs was developed. Based on currently available analytical standards, the method can be used to determine the concentrations of GenX and two additional PFEAs (perfluoromethoxypropanoic acid and perfluoroethoxypropanoic acid) that have been identified in North Carolina (NC) surface water, groundwater, and drinking water. The limit of quantitation (LOQ) for the liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method is 10 ng/L for each PFEA. The analytical method targets five additional PFEAs [perfluoromethoxyacetic acid (PFMOAA), perfluorodioxahexanoic acid (PFO2HxA), perfluorotrioxaoctanoic acid (PFO3OA), perfluorotetraoxadecanoic acid (PFO4DA), Nafion by-product 2] that have been identified in NC drinking water, but for which analytical standards are currently not available. A semi-quantitative approach for estimating their concentrations was developed.

With respect to the second goal, water samples collected from the Cape Fear River were analyzed to determine dominant PFEAs at three drinking water intake locations in the watershed. Initial occurrence data demonstrated that eight PFEAs were present in the river. At the time of the initial sample analysis, only one PFEA, GenX, could be quantified with the use of an analytical standard. While GenX was not detected upstream of a fluorochemical manufacturing site, its average concentration was 630 ng/L at a downstream drinking water intake location. Peak areas of three PFEAs (PFMOAA, PFO2HxA, and PFO3OA) exceeded that of GenX, and the peak area of PFMOAA exceeded that of GenX by more than two orders of magnitude.

Upon further method development, additional sampling campaigns were conducted in the late Spring and Summer of 2017. In mid-June, the sum concentration of all targeted PFEAs was estimated at ~40,000 ng/L, with dominant contributions from PFMOAA >> PFO2HxA > PFO3OA ~ GenX > Nafion by-product 2. When the fluorochemical manufacturer began to capture process wastewater in late June, the sum concentration of targeted PFEAs in the river dropped sharply to an estimated concentration of ~4,200 ng/L by mid-July, 2017 and to ~500 ng/L by the end of September 2017.

Water samples were also collected after each step of the water treatment process in a full-scale water treatment plant. Neither conventional nor advanced treatment processes such as ozonation, biofiltration, and disinfection by medium pressure ultraviolet (UV) lamps were effective for attenuating PFEA concentrations. Results from laboratory-scale adsorption experiments showed that several PFEAs were poorly adsorbable by powdered activated carbon. Furthermore, PFEA concentrations remained similar throughout the distribution system, as monitored at several residences across the affected communities.

Finally, a field evaluation of home filtration devices illustrated that only devices containing reverse osmosis membranes were effective for PFEA removal from tap water. Adsorption processes were able to partially remove some PFEAs, but short-chain PFEAs such as PFMOAA were poorly removed.

With respect to the third goal, data collected during this research raised awareness about PFEAs, such as GenX, not only in North Carolina, but also in several other states across the US. Results of initial sampling campaigns along the Cape Fear River and in a drinking water treatment plant were published in a peer-reviewed journal article and served as the basis for an investigative report in the Wilmington Star Newspaper, that was published on June 8, 2017 and raised community awareness about high PFEA levels in the local drinking water. Subsequently, the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services developed a health goal of 140 ng/L for GenX. Concurrently, efforts by the fluorochemical manufacturer and the North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality have led to a dramatic decline in PFEA concentrations in the drinking water of more than 200,000 North Carolinians.
